extendedMetadata.value: LO: 14.1: How did territorial expansion intensify the conflict over slave?

subject: US History
metadata.bookAuthor: H. W. Brands; T. H. Breen; R. Hal Williams; Ariela J. Gros
metadata.title: FA Remember 14 01

config.question: During the 1840s, how did the majority of antislavery Northerners feel about abolitionism?

choices.content: They saw it as a moral obligation.
They saw it as integral to the American system of equal rights.
They supported it on principle but not in their voting patterns.

answer_3.response: Consider This: Northerners saw no legal or desirable way to bring about emancipation of blacks within the southern states. They were inclined to view slavery as a backward and unwholesome institution, much inferior to their own free-labor system, and could be persuaded that slaveholders were power-hungry aristocrats seeking more than their share of national political influence. See L.O. 14.1 How did territorial expansion intensify the conflict over slave?
